4th Order 
Blewish green 36 27 23 1/4
Green 37 2/3 28 1/4 24 1/3
Yellowish green 39 1/3 29 1/2 25 1/3
Red 44 33 28 1/3
5 Order
Greenish blew 50 2/3 38 32 2/3
Red 57 1/3 43 37
6t Order 
Greenish blew 64 48 41 1/3
Red 70 2/3 53 45 2/3
7th Order 
Greenish blew 77 1/3 58 50
Red or white 84 63 54 1/2

4th Order 
Blewish green 36 27 23 1/4
Green 37 2/3 28 1/4 24 1/3
Yellowish green 39 1/3 29 1/2 25 1/3
Red 44 33 28 1/3
5 Order
Greenish blew 50 2/3 38 32 2/3
Red 57 1/3 43 37
6t Order 
Greenish blew 64 48 41 1/3
Red 70 2/3 53 45 2/3
7th Order 
Greenish blew 77 1/3 58 50
Red or white 84 63 54 1/2

Now if this Table be compared with the third scheme you 
will there see the constituc[i]on of each colour as to its 
ingredientes or the Originall colours of wch it is compounded,
& thence be enabled to judge of its intensenesse or Imperfection 
wch may Suffice in explicac[i]on of the 4th and 18th Observac[i]ons,
unless it be further desired to delineate the manner, how ye 
colours appear when the two Object glasses are layd upon one 
another. To doe wch, let there be described a large Arc of a 
Circle and a Streight Line, wch may touch that Arc, and 
paralell to that Tangent Seu[er]all occult Lines at such 
distances from it as the numbers, sett against the seu[er]all 
colours in the Table, Denote. For the Arc & its Tangent 
will represent the superficies of the Glasses terminating the 
interjacent Air, & the places where the occult lines cutt ye 
Arc will show at what distances from the Center or point of 
Contact each colour is reflected.
There are alsoe other uses of this Table. For by its 
Assistance the thicknes of the Bubble in the 19th Observac[i]on 
was determined by the colours wch it exhibited. And so the 
bignesse of the partes of naturall Bodyes may be conjectured 
at by their colours, as shall be hereafter showne. Also if two 
or more very thin plates be layd one upon another so as to 
compose one plate, equalling them all in thickness, the 
resulting colour may be hereby determined. For instance, Mr.
Hook in his Micrographia observes, that a faint yellow plate 
of Moscovy Glasse, laid upon a blew one, constituted a very deep 
purple. The yellow of the first Order is a faint one and the 
thicknes of the plate Exhibiting it, according to the Table,
is 5 1/4, to wch add 9 1/2 the thicknesse exhibiting Blew of the 
Second Order, & the Summe will be 14 3/4, wch most nearly 
approaches 14 4/5 the thicknesse exhibiting the Purple of 
the third Order
To explaine in the next place the circumstances of the 
Second & 3d Observac[i]ons, that is, how the colours (by 
turning the Prisms about their comon Axis the contrary 
way to that expressed in those Observac[i]ons) may be converted 
into
